comments.text:
You do realize what percent means right? Percent is derived from Latin 
percent being short for per centum which translates to perhundred. It 
doesn't matter how many people there are a percent is a fraction of a 
whole. For example 16% percent of children under 6 pick there nose (not an 
actual statistic) that literally means the 16/100 kids pick their nose.

be allergic too. Yes it could be possible But that wouldn't even be a 
reliable or significant number because 1) no one really knows WHY our 
immune system overreacted. 2) if the allergic ppl are passing on genes 
wouldn't the not allergic people be passing on there genes as well? So when 
a mom is allergic and a dad isn't then their child has a 50/50 chance of 
being allergic. Again, no one really knows why exactly the percentage of 
peanut allergy is increasing but I find that your claim that people who are 
allergic are Just reprising more is just implausible
comments.author: Tatertots Boo

comments.text:
You don't even know what percentage are do you... sigh... I'm just so 
disappointed in humanity right now. Ok let me try to re-teach you and break 
it down as simple as possible. A percent is a number over a whole. For 
example: out of 100 people, 20 are allergic (20%). Out of 200 people 40 are 
allergic (20%). Out of 1000 people 200 are effected (20%) etc. If the total 
number of people increase and out of those people, less and less are being 
affected by peanuts then we say "percentages decrease" But out of the total 
number of people, more and more people are Being affected than we say 
"percentage increase". For instance: in 2005, there was 1000 kids in a town 
and 200 were allergic to peanuts (that's 20%). But in 2010, there were 2000 
kids total and 1000 kids were allergic (that's 50%), 20%- 50% is an 
increase. As you can see, a percentage is a number over a whole (I really 
hope you know that). let's say in 2005, 500 out of 1000 kids were allergic 
(50%). And in 2010, 500/2000 Are allergic (25%). 50%- 25% is a decrease. 
Percentages are based on proportions so what you stated made no sense.
comments.author: Tatertots Boo

comments.author: synapse131

comments.text:
That's actually a supported hypothesis. The main claim is that a lack of 
introduction to parasites causes them, because our defense mechanisms 
against parasites do the same things that the 'defense' for allergens does, 
like opening blood vessels (hives & severe blood pressure drop), and 
constricting the airways to prepare to throw up the parasite if it can't be 
eradicated any other way (nausea, cramps, throwing up, trouble breathing). 
Except because our bodies can't properly fight the "parasite," the cycle 
continues until the lack of air or drop in blood pressure kills the person.
comments.author: MegaSupernova888

you are wrong.

Evolution:
We (life on earth, not humans specifically) evolved on Earth, therefore, we 
evolved *for* earth, and therefore, we are perfect for earth.

Creationism:
A creator created earth, and then created life for earth, therefore life on 
earth is perfect for earth.

comments.text:
+Xcoming2 if the world didn't function perfectly, you wouldn't exist to 
reflect on the fact that it doesn't function perfectly.

You are only able to reflect on the fact that this world functions 
perfectly *because* it functions perfectly.

We observe a world that functions perfectly because that is all that is 
possible. Whether we were created by evolution or a creator, we came into

comments.author: BillyJoe1305

comments.text:
There's actually an interesting hypothesis that's becoming more recognized 
in the food allergy community - parasites. In the Western world, we are 
extremely clean. So clean, in fact, that parasites are mostly not a worry. 
However, there's still a mechanism in our bodies for defending against 
them. With virtually no purpose in parasite-free countries, the system 
begins mislabeling certain proteins as 'parasites' and begins performing 
the functions it normally would to no avail.

The system is supposed to open up the blood vessels so that extra blood 
cells can fight off the parasite, along with constricting the airways in 
case the parasite has to be thrown up.

Because this doesn't work for the proteins, people experience hives (from 
the leaking blood vessels), nausea & cramps (from the 'throwing up' 
response), trouble breathing (from the 'throwing up' response) and severe 
drops in blood pressure (from the blood leaving the vessels).

I'm sure some of this must rely on genes, but I think environmental factors 
would have a greater influence on this.
comments.author: MegaSupernova888

top_comment.text:
I have come to suspect that the current unpopularity of breast feeding 
infants may be a factor in the rising rates of allergies in the developed 
world, particularly the US.  Many factors with long term effects are being 
found by medical and even evolutionary researchers. But little is 
understood about many of the things in breast milk. The role it plays in 
developing the immune system appears to be very important.

Not suggesting that is THE cause but that it may be an important factor.﻿
top_comment.author: MacNutz2

I am surprised that gut microbes was not mentioned. Since autoimmunity and 
food intolerance are related to our gut flora because our colon is where 
many reguatory T cells which is responsible for immune tolerance are being 
produced, anyone who has an inflammed gut and having certain species of gut 
microbes wiped out are prone to have autoimmunity and food 
intolerance including peanut allergy. 

Factors such as bad diet, baby milk formula, over-sanitized habit or the 
over-use of antibiotics all contribute to the prevelance of these problems.

sometime. I would've had 15-16 years of exposure to the sorts of pollen 
that would be found in my vicinity.
comments.author: William Smith

comments.text:
I actually think that the cause of allergies, or at least seasonal ones 
(pollen and other reproductive plant stuff) could be due to deprivation of 
that compound. Let's say you don't get exposed to pollen until the age of 
4, by then, the immune system is either fully developed, or almost, the 
pollen is something brand new entering your body, and your immune system 
has no record of it, and goes into over-protective mode.
comments.author: Zeldagigafan

top_comment.text:
You know what would be an interesting science topic? Why Americans (or 
North Americans) are more prone to food allergies than other countries. 
Things like gluten allergies which don't seem to exist outside of the US. 
Allergies to lactose, peanuts, etc., seem to be less of a concern in other 
countries.

It would also be interesting to see if these allergies are manifested in 
places outside of the US when introduced to processed foods that are so 
prevalent in the US.﻿
top_comment.author: Randall Collins

comments.text:
It's because in the US people rarely get breastfed, and are raised in 
super-clean pathogen-free environements where they don't develop necessary 
immune functions. GMOs and C-Sections also may play a part in this.
comments.author: Another Wannabe

comments.text:
Lactose intolerance is actually more common in countries that don't have 
populations of European descent.

top_comment.text:
I'm not allergic or anything, but for the sake of those who are, factories 
need to stop producing chocolate on the same conveyor belts as anything 
with nuts in them. Pretty much every chocolate rapper I have that doesn't 
cover chocolate with nuts in it says "If you're allergic to any kind of 
nut, don't eat this delicious snack, because we're too lazy to make it on a 
separate production line in the factory. But don't worry, we didn't intend 
this delicious snack to have nuts in it..."﻿
top_comment.author: PyroOfZen

comments.text:
+PyroOfZen they aren't lazy. it's cost efficient. Businesses aren't in 
business to kiss your ass, they are in business to make money. not being 
able to sell to the 1% of the population allergic to peanuts doesn't hurt 
sales.
comments.author: Soupy

comments.text:
It says it may contain nuts so if one chocolate bar happens to have a bit 
of nut on it for some reason the company can say that they warned you and 
you can't sue them
comments.author: Alex bob bajaj

comments.text:
+JWQweqOPDH I eat plenty of chocolate that literally say that they were 
made on the same production line as nut-filled products on the wrapper. Of 
course, it's more common to see a simple: "May contain traces of nuts."
comments.author: PyroOfZen

comments.text:
As the other guy said, what the rapper says does not mean to tell you that 
it was made on the same production line, it's a requirement whenever the 
food was made within the same facility as foods containing allergens.
comments.author: JWQweqOPDH

comments.text:
Yay, then all of these delicious snacks can cost 6 times as much. OOooh, I

pressure this puts on every other item in our food line, demand prices 
everything is suspect. You must be some kind of genius.

comments.text:
that's not how it works, they are very strict with the conditions to say 
that it's nut free, you can't produce it on a different production line, 
you would have to produce it in a different factory, even dust carried 
through air is enough to create a big problem.

in a factory they have 2 separate sections, walled off from eachother, 
bringing any nuts into the chocolate section is strictly forbidden, but 
guess what, they are still branded as "could potentially contain traces of 
nuts". They don't want to be sued for potentially killing anyone.

captions.text:
Is 
it just me or are more people allergic to
peanuts now than ever before? What's going
on? Why are we allergic to these little things?

Peanuts are delicious. They're free on airplanes,
and though I'm not a huge fan of peanut butter

unless it's on a granny smith apple -- it's
a very popular thing in the US. And yet, peanut

allergies are becoming an epidemic! Or…
maybe they're not, and we're just freaking
out. Humans do that.

Firstly, there are two negative ways your
body can react to food. Allergic reaction,

or intolerance. An intolerance is like indigestion,
your body isn't HAPPY with the food you've

consumed, but it's not dangerous. The VAST
majority of people who react to peanuts and

other foods have intolerances. If you can
eat a peanut accidentally and not die, but

you won't feel great, you probably are intolerant,
not allergic.

The FDA says 90 percent of all food allergies
are caused by milk or dairy, eggs, certain

fish and shellfish, wheat, soybeans, tree
nuts and peanuts. If you accidentally eat

even a tiny bit of these and are allergic,
you'd have a severe and rapid reaction. Allergies

are your immune system freaking out and attacking
what it thinks is a pathogen. Though food

allergies are a growing problem, only 8-percent
of children have them, and of those less than

40 percent react severely. According to a
2010 study by Mount Sinai Hospital, only 1.4

percent of children were allergic to peanuts
specifically, and other numbers are even lower.

Pollen, by contrast, affects as many as 1
in 5 people according to The Asthma and Allergy

Foundation! But, of course, pollen doesn't
cause anaphylaxis -- or a potentially fatal

immune reaction that can be so strong it inhibits
breathing. The CDC, though, says deaths are

rare -- only 17 people from 1979 to 1995 -- way
fewer than died from lightning strikes.

That being said, we ARE getting more allergic
to things. It's growing. The number of people

allergic to peanuts has tripled since the
late 70s, and scientists don't know why…

Even still, they're working on solutions.
A 2014 study in the journal JAMA Pediatric

found if moms consumed peanuts while pregnant,
the kid in the womb had a much lower risk

of developing the peanut allergy! Perhaps
part of the rise is because moms are eating

fewer peanuts? Scientists figure the early
exposure to tiny levels of peanut proteins

will help prep the developing fetus so they
don't freak out when they meet them on the
outside. But again, they aren't sure.

Since we know the allergic population is growing,
there are lots of steps being taken to protect

kids. A University of Florida study this week
found pulsing UV light onto peanuts eroded

an allergen protein called "ARA h1-h3" to
a QUOTE "undetectable level."

A University of Florida study this week found
pulsing UV light onto peanuts eroded the allergen

proteins ARA h1, h2 and h3 to a QUOTE "undetectable
level."

According to the report, they can cut the
allergens so 95 percent of people with allergies

would be safe! It might be extreme, but it
could mean a lot for the piece of mind at
school cafeterias.

In the end, kids CAN and often DO grow out
of their youthful allergies. There ARE schools

that have banned peanut butter -- much to
the chagrin American Academy of Allergy, Asthma

and Immunology, The Food Allergy & Anaphylaxis
Network and other parents. They all agree,

bans aren't the answer. It's better to treat
each child with their individual allergy symptoms,
as those symptoms arise.

Are you allergic to peanuts or intolerant?
What do you think is causing all these allergies?!

title: Why Are Peanut Allergies Becoming So Common?
